quotes.text: A question that get asked a lot and a lot is, "How do we keep up to date with the latest AI news?" Why do you need to keep up to date with the latest AI news? If you talk to the users who understand what they want or they don't want, look into the feedback, then you can actually improve the application way, way, way more.
quotes.speaker: Chip Huyen
quotes.context: A contrarian prioritization model: user feedback loops can outperform chasing AI news for improving real products.

quotes.text: We are in an ideal crisis. Now, we have all this really cool tools to do everything from scratch and have new design. It can have you write code. You can have new website. So in theory, we should see a lot more, but at the same time, people are somehow stuck. They don't know what to build.
quotes.speaker: Chip Huyen
quotes.context: A memorable diagnosis of the current moment: tooling abundance doesn’t solve product direction, and teams get stuck on “what to build.”

quotes.text: It's really hard to measure productivity. So, I do ask people to ask their managers, "Would you rather give everyone on the team very expensive coding agent subscriptions or you get an extra head count?" Almost every one, the managers will say head count. But if you ask VP level or someone who manage a lot of teams, they would say, "Want AI assistant." Because as managers, you are still growing, so for you having one HR head count is big. Whereas for executives, maybe you have more business metrics that you care about. So you actually think about what actually drive productivity metrics for you.
quotes.speaker: Chip Huyen
quotes.context: A practical litmus test for AI ROI and adoption: compare “AI subscriptions vs headcount” and note how incentives differ by management level.

quotes.text: Design teams today are expected to move fast but also to get it right.
quotes.speaker: Sponsor (Dscout read)
quotes.context: Captures the core product/design tension between speed and quality that teams must actively manage.

quotes.text: Whether you're running usability tests, interviews, surveys, or in the wild field work, Dscout makes it easy to connect with real users and get real insights fast.
quotes.speaker: Sponsor (Dscout read)
quotes.context: Actionable reminder to use multiple research methods while prioritizing rapid access to real users.

quotes.text: My team is spread out across Colorado, Australia, Nepal, West Africa, and San Francisco.
quotes.speaker: Sponsor (Justworks read)
quotes.context: A concrete example of a globally distributed team, highlighting real operational complexity practitioners may face.

quotes.text: My life would be so incredibly complicated to hire people internationally, to pay people on time and in their local currencies, and to answer their HR questions 24/7.
quotes.speaker: Sponsor (Justworks read)
quotes.context: Enumerates the practical pain points of international hiring and operations that leaders should plan for.

quotes.text: They do your human resources right so that you can do right by your people.
quotes.speaker: Sponsor (Justworks read)
quotes.context: A memorable principle framing HR as an enabler of better people leadership rather than just compliance.

quotes.text: I think it went super viral because it hit a nerve with a lot of people.
quotes.speaker: Lenny Rachitsky
quotes.context: Frames the segment’s core premise: the table resonated because it calls out common misprioritization in AI app building.

quotes.text: Why? Why do you need to keep up to date with the latest AI news?
quotes.speaker: Chip Huyen
quotes.context: A contrarian challenge to the default behavior of chasing AI news instead of focusing on fundamentals that move product outcomes.

quotes.text: First, how much of the improvement could you get from optimal solutions versus non-optimal solutions?
quotes.speaker: Chip Huyen
quotes.context: A practical decision-making test for tech debates: quantify the marginal gains before investing time in “best” choices.

quotes.text: Okay, if it's not much improvement, then why do you want to spend so much time debating something that doesn't make that much difference to your performance?
quotes.speaker: Chip Huyen
quotes.context: Actionable prioritization advice: stop spending cycles on low-impact optimizations and redirect effort to higher-leverage work.

quotes.text: let's say here's a new technology. It hasn't been tested by a lot of people, and if you would adopt it, you would be stuck with it forever. Do you actually want to adopt it?
quotes.speaker: Chip Huyen
quotes.context: A memorable risk framework for adopting unproven tech: evaluate lock-in and switching costs before committing.

quotes.text: I think of language modeling as a way of encoding statistical information about language, right?
quotes.speaker: Chip Huyen
quotes.context: A crisp mental model for what pre-training is actually doing: learning statistical regularities of language rather than “understanding” in a human sense.

quotes.text: So I think my sampling strategy, I think is something extremely important. It can have you boost a performance in a huge way and very, very underrated.
quotes.speaker: Chip Huyen
quotes.context: Actionable reminder that inference-time choices (sampling) can materially improve results without changing the model or training.

quotes.text: So the vast majority of time, we don't touch on pre-training model. As users, we don't use it at all.
quotes.speaker: Chip Huyen
quotes.context: Counterintuitive framing that practitioners mostly live in post-training/inference layers, not raw pre-trained checkpoints.

quotes.text: So let's say that we have the new word, how to say it, like podcasting, right? Let's say it's a new word, but it can divide a podcast and ing.
quotes.speaker: Chip Huyen
quotes.context: Concrete example explaining why tokenization matters and how models generalize to new words via subword pieces.

quotes.text: So the idea is that once you [inaudible 00:16:14]... So let's say you have a model, give the model a prompt and it produce an output. You want to buy, once you reinforce, encourage the model to produce an output that is better. So now it comes to how do we know that the answer is good or bad? So usually, people relies on signals.
quotes.speaker: Chip Huyen
quotes.context: Frames RL for LLMs as a loop of generating outputs and improving them using explicit “signals” that define good vs. bad behavior.

quotes.text: They happen to be have two responses. You can, okay, this one one's better than the other. And we do that is because as humans, we tend to, it's very hard to give a concrete score, but it's easier to do comparisons.
quotes.speaker: Chip Huyen
quotes.context: Explains why pairwise preference data is often more reliable and scalable than absolute ratings when collecting human feedback.

quotes.text: If you ask me, okay, give this song a score, I'm not a musician and don't know how hard it is. It's like yeah, I don't know what, out of 10 I going to remove six. And if you ask me again a month from now and I completely forgotten, okay, maybe now seven, only four, I don't know. But then if you ask me, okay, here are two songs and which one would you prefer to play for the birthday party? I was like, "Okay, I can prefer this song."
quotes.speaker: Chip Huyen
quotes.context: A concrete example showing how absolute scoring is inconsistent while comparisons stay stable—useful guidance for designing feedback tasks.

quotes.text: Another ways you can, instead of using a human, so you can use AI because the response and say good or bad, right? Or in fact the thing is that people are very big on nowadays, verifiable rewards, which it's natural. So basically, they give it a math problem and then math solutions is a model app a solution. Okay, it's expected response should be 42 and if it doesn't provide 42, then it's wrong. Now it's not a good response.
quotes.speaker: Chip Huyen
quotes.context: Outlines three practical reward-signal sources—human, AI, and verifiable rewards—with a crisp “expected response should be 42” example.

quotes.text: I think it's general, it's a way of learning. It's training is [inaudible 00:18:33] learning and whether it learn from human feedback or AI feedback or verifiable rewards, I think I say it's just different way of collating signals.
quotes.speaker: Chip Huyen
quotes.context: A unifying mental model: RLHF variants differ mainly in how they collect signals, not in the underlying learning goal.

quotes.topic_title: Domain expert data and labeling economics
quotes.text: there are so many domain expert task that the model developers want models to do well on, right? Let's say you're accountant. Maybe you want to use a model to have accounting task and need a lot of accounting data examples from accountant. So you need to hire a lot of them
quotes.speaker: Chip Huyen
quotes.context: Highlights the practical implication that high-performing domain models often require hiring real domain experts to generate training examples.

quotes.topic_title: Domain expert data and labeling economics
quotes.text: I'm not sure what apps you use, but maybe like a [inaudible 00:20:04] app or QuickBooks or Google Excel. They have very specific tools, specific expertise. So you want the model [inaudible 00:20:13] learn.
quotes.speaker: Chip Huyen
quotes.context: Points to a concrete data strategy: capture expertise tied to specific professional tools/workflows, not just generic domain knowledge.

quotes.topic_title: Domain expert data and labeling economics
quotes.text: I thought it's very interesting [inaudible 00:20:35] think about because it's very lopsided, right? Because they're only a very small numbers of frontier labs and they want a lot of data and there's a massive amount of startups or company providing related data.
quotes.speaker: Chip Huyen
quotes.context: Provides a market-structure mental model (few buyers, many sellers) that affects pricing power and vendor strategy in labeling/data services.

quotes.topic_title: Domain expert data and labeling economics
quotes.text: I'm a little bit like [inaudible 00:21:08] uneasy. I have a company's growing crazy, but it's heavily dependent on two or three companies.
quotes.speaker: Chip Huyen
quotes.context: A cautionary observation for practitioners evaluating vendors or building data businesses: growth can mask concentrated-customer risk.

quotes.topic_title: Domain expert data and labeling economics
quotes.text: Now I want a lot of startups. I want to have a lot of providers so I can pick and choose, and as this providers can also to compete each other to lower the price
quotes.speaker: Chip Huyen
quotes.context: Explains the buyer-side playbook frontier labs may use—multi-sourcing to increase leverage and drive down labeling costs.

quotes.topic_title: Evals: what they are and why
quotes.text: So I think people approach eval, I think they're two very different problems.
quotes.speaker: Chip Huyen
quotes.context: Sets up a useful mental model that “evals” split into distinct categories depending on whether you’re building an app or improving a model.

quotes.topic_title: Evals: what they are and why
quotes.text: One is a app builder and can I say have an app that do maybe a chatbot? Very simple answer first thing that came to my mind and I want you to know if chatbot is good or bad. So it needs to come away with evaluate the chatbot.
quotes.speaker: Chip Huyen
quotes.context: Grounds evals in a practical, app-level goal: deciding whether a real product experience is “good or bad.”

quotes.topic_title: Evals: what they are and why
quotes.text: Another thing is, I think of this as a task-specific eval design. So let's say I'm a model developer and I want to make my model better at code writing. And it was like, "Okay, but how do I even measure code writing?"
quotes.speaker: Chip Huyen
quotes.context: Highlights the harder, often-missed part of evals: defining what “better” means for a specific capability like code writing.

quotes.topic_title: Evals: what they are and why
quotes.text: So I need someone to understand code writing and think about what makes a story good and then design the whole dataset and then criteria to evaluate code writing.
quotes.speaker: Chip Huyen
quotes.context: Describes an actionable methodology: domain understanding → quality criteria → dataset design → evaluation criteria.

quotes.topic_title: Evals: what they are and why
quotes.text: So I guess, [inaudible 00:23:49], I think eval is really, really fun because it's extremely creative.
quotes.speaker: Chip Huyen
quotes.context: Counteracts the common assumption that evals are dry, reframing them as creative work that can attract strong builders.

quotes.topic_title: Do AI products need evals or vibes?
quotes.text: You don't have to be absolutely perfect, I think, to win. You just need to be good enough and being consistent about it.
quotes.speaker: Chip Huyen
quotes.context: A pragmatic bar-setting principle for AI product quality: optimize for “good enough + consistency” rather than perfection.

quotes.topic_title: Do AI products need evals or vibes?
quotes.text: And it was like, "Okay, but [inaudible 00:25:35] that two engineers and we going to launch a new feature, then it could give me so much more improvement."
quotes.speaker: Chip Huyen
quotes.context: Frames eval investment as an ROI tradeoff versus shipping new features that may drive larger gains.

quotes.topic_title: Do AI products need evals or vibes?
quotes.text: So yeah, so I do think eval is very, very important if you have, if you operate a scale and where failures can have catastrophic consequences.
quotes.speaker: Chip Huyen
quotes.context: Clear decision rule: eval rigor becomes non-negotiable when scale and downside risk are high.

quotes.topic_title: Do AI products need evals or vibes?
quotes.text:
But it's just something that's more a low-key, okay, this is like something is like, okay, that's not the core but it helps with our users.

Then maybe you don't need to be so obsessed or theoretical about it. It's like, okay, that's good enough for now and if it fails, then it fails.
quotes.speaker: Chip Huyen
quotes.context: A counterintuitive prioritization heuristic: for non-core features, accept “good enough” and tolerate failure rather than over-investing in evals.

quotes.topic_title: How many evals and where to apply them
quotes.text: I don't think of just a fixed number on the evals. What was the goal of eval? The goal of eval is to guide the product development.
quotes.speaker: Chip Huyen
quotes.context: Reframes evals from a checklist/number target into a tool whose scope should be driven by product-development needs.

quotes.topic_title: How many evals and where to apply them
quotes.text: So sometimes, we've seen a very obvious [inaudible 00:28:15] where you look at the eval and we realize it's like, okay, it performed really poorly on this specific segment of users and then we look into it's like, okay, what's wrong with it? And it turns out, it's like we just don't have a good messaging to it.
quotes.speaker: Chip Huyen
quotes.context: Shows how evals can diagnose issues outside the model itself (e.g., messaging), guiding high-leverage fixes.

quotes.topic_title: How many evals and where to apply them
quotes.text: Yeah, so I kind of like the number of eval is really depends. We have seen product with hundreds of different metrics.
quotes.speaker: Chip Huyen
quotes.context: Counteracts the common “just a handful of evals” heuristic by noting real-world products may require extensive metric coverage.

quotes.topic_title: How many evals and where to apply them
quotes.text: So every step of the way, you need evaluations. You don't [inaudible 00:30:21] end-to-end.
quotes.speaker: Chip Huyen
quotes.context: Advocates stepwise evaluation for complex workflows (like deep research) rather than relying only on end-to-end scoring.

quotes.topic_title: How many evals and where to apply them
quotes.text: So I don't think it's how many eval should I get, but how many eval do I need to get a good coverage, a high confidence in my application's performance and also to help me understand where it is not performing well so that I can fix it.
quotes.speaker: Chip Huyen
quotes.context: Provides a practical decision rule: choose evals to maximize coverage, confidence, and debuggability—not to hit a number.

quotes.text: I think that's what RAG is, as a simplest sense, it's just providing the model with a relevant context so that it can answer the questions.
quotes.speaker: Chip Huyen
quotes.context: A crisp mental model of RAG that practitioners can use to align design decisions around “relevant context.”

quotes.text: I just want to say this data preparations for RAG is extremely important. And I would say this in a lot of the companies that I have seen, that's the biggest performance, in their RAG solutions coming from better data preparations, not agonizing over what [inaudible 00:34:51] databases to use
quotes.speaker: Chip Huyen
quotes.context: Counterintuitive prioritization: quality gains often come more from data prep than from choosing a vector database.

quotes.text: So we have think about how big of each chunk should be. Because if it's sort of think about it's a context you want to maximize, maybe you can, it's very simple example. You want to retrieve a thousand words. So if a data chunk is long, then it's more likely to contain more relevant metadata so it can retrieve more. But if it's too long then you have a thousand word. And so chunk is like a thousand words, you can reach one chunk. So it's not very useful. But if it's too short, then you can retrieve more relevant information also. It can retrieve a wider range of documents and chunks, but at the same time each chunk is too small to contain relevant information.
quotes.speaker: Chip Huyen
quotes.context: A practical chunking tradeoff framework (recall vs. usefulness) with a concrete “retrieve a thousand words” example.

quotes.text: Somebody was telling me just a very big performance they got is that from rewriting their data in the question-answering format. Instead of having... So they have a podcast instead of just chunking the podcast, you just reframe, rewrite it into here's a question, here's answers and produce a lot of them. It can use AI for that as well.
quotes.speaker: Chip Huyen
quotes.context: Actionable methodology: convert source content into QA pairs to materially improve retrieval and answer quality.

quotes.text: Usually a lot of documentation today is written for human reading and AI reading is different because it's different because humans, we have common sense and we kind of know what it is.
quotes.speaker: Chip Huyen
quotes.context: A useful reframing: documentation often needs an “AI-readable” layer because models lack implicit human context.

quotes.text: We talk a lot on this podcast about the amazing advances in AI, but this can be a double-edged sword.
quotes.speaker: Lenny Rachitsky
quotes.context: A memorable mental model that frames AI progress as simultaneously enabling value and new attack surfaces.

quotes.text: For every wow moment, there are fraudsters using the same tech to wreak havoc, laundering money, taking over employee identities and impersonating businesses.
quotes.speaker: Lenny Rachitsky
quotes.context: A counterintuitive reminder that AI capability gains often translate directly into scaled fraud and security threats.

quotes.text: Persona helps combat these threats with automated user business and employee verification.
quotes.speaker: Lenny Rachitsky
quotes.context: Actionable guidance: mitigate AI-enabled fraud by investing in automated verification across user and employee flows.

quotes.text: Best of all, Persona makes it easy to know who you're dealing with without adding friction for good users.
quotes.speaker: Lenny Rachitsky
quotes.context: A practical product principle: security/verification should minimize added friction for legitimate users.

quotes.text: The data is actually showing most companies try it. Doesn't do a lot, they stop.
quotes.speaker: Lenny Rachitsky
quotes.context: A pointed adoption observation that challenges hype by emphasizing drop-off when early AI efforts fail to deliver impact.

quotes.topic_title: Enterprise GenAI adoption and productivity measurement
quotes.text: I do have this theory of a lot of applications companies pursue because they can't measure the concrete outcome.
quotes.speaker: Chip Huyen
quotes.context: A practical lens for why enterprises gravitate toward certain GenAI projects: measurability drives prioritization as much as value.

quotes.topic_title: Enterprise GenAI adoption and productivity measurement
quotes.text: The main thing is it's really hard to measure productivity again.
quotes.speaker: Chip Huyen
quotes.context: Pinpoints the core blocker behind stalled internal GenAI adoption: unclear productivity measurement makes ROI hard to justify.

quotes.topic_title: Enterprise GenAI adoption and productivity measurement
quotes.text: Would you rather give everyone on the team very expensive coding agent subscriptions or you get an extra headcount?
quotes.speaker: Chip Huyen
quotes.context: A concrete decision test leaders can use to surface how different management layers value AI tools versus staffing.

quotes.topic_title: Enterprise GenAI adoption and productivity measurement
quotes.text: But if you ask VP level or someone who manage a lot of teams, they would say just like [inaudible 00:44:48] good one, AI, a system as tools.
quotes.speaker: Chip Huyen
quotes.context: Counterintuitive observation that executive-level incentives can favor AI tooling even when frontline managers prefer headcount.

quotes.topic_title: Enterprise GenAI adoption and productivity measurement
quotes.text: The biggest performance boost [inaudible 00:46:41] the senior engineer, the highest performing. So the highest performing engineer get the biggest boost out of it.
quotes.speaker: Chip Huyen
quotes.context: A specific (and surprising) experiment result suggesting AI coding tools may amplify top performers more than help struggling engineers.
